general: This law allows the UK government to approve changes made by other EU countries to the rules about how the Eurozone works. The changes are meant to help countries in the Eurozone who are having financial problems, like Greece or Ireland. The UK government needs to agree to these changes before they can be put into effect. This law helps ensure that the UK is part of the agreement and that the changes are done properly.

series.short: "EU Stability Mechanism Approved: UK Legislation Enacted"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The European Union (Approval of Treaty Amendment Decision) Act 2012 approves the European Council's decision to establish a stability mechanism for member states using the Euro currency.
* Simplified point 2: The act ensures that the decision does not require a referendum under the European Union Act 2011.
* Simplified point 3: The act extends to the entire United Kingdom and comes into force on the day it is passed.
* Simplified point 4: The act may be cited as the European Union (Approval of Treaty Amendment Decision) Act 2012.

summary: The European Union (Approval of Treaty Amendment Decision) Act 2012 helps keep the economies of countries using the Euro currency stable by creating a special fund to support them during difficult times. This law says that the UK government can agree to this fund without needing to ask the public's opinion through a vote. It applies across the whole of the UK and came into effect as soon as it was passed.
single:
• This act approves the European Council decision of 25 March 2011 amending Article 136 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union with regard to a stability mechanism for Member States whose currency is the euro.
• The decision does not require a referendum under the European Union Act 2011.
• The act extends to the whole of the United Kingdom and comes into force on the day it is passed.
• The act may be cited as the European Union (Approval of Treaty Amendment Decision) Act 2012.
• The decision aims to establish a stability mechanism for eurozone member states to ensure their financial stability and prevent a crisis like the one in 2008 from happening again.
• The decision will allow the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) to provide financial assistance to member states in need, provided they meet certain conditions.
• The decision will also allow for the establishment of a European Single Resolution Fund to help resolve failing banks in the eurozone.
• The decision will impact eurozone member states, particularly those that are struggling financially, such as Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and Spain.
